Award.AwardTitle: MATH:EAGER: Guide to Evidenced-Based Instructional Practices in Undergraduate Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A strong background in mathematics is expected of college graduates so that they can thrive in the workforce as science, technology, engineering, mathematics (STEM) professionals, and professionals in other technical and non-technical fields, as well as citizens able to navigate the variety of information available through the media and other sources. To this end, there have been efforts in the mathematical sciences to improve the learning and teaching of undergraduate mathematics. A body of research on learning and teaching now exists that provides evidence pointing to effective strategies for teaching of mathematics to college students. This project will produce an instructional practices guide to emphasize evidence-based student-centered pedagogies. This instructional practices guide will serve as a research-based resource for mathematics instructors, both faculty and graduate students, at all types of higher education institutions.

The Mathematical Association of America (MAA) is the largest professional organization focused on undergraduate mathematics and is the leading source for mathematics faculty professional development as well as resources for teaching and learning undergraduate mathematics. As such, the MAA is the natural and optimal lead organization to produce a resource intended to infuse research-based pedagogies into the teaching of undergraduate mathematics. For each topic addressed, the instructional practices guide will include a summary and synthesis of current literature on that topic. In producing these summaries, the project team expects to discover areas of research in which the evidence-base is better developed than for others. Thus, the project will also address two primary research questions: (1) What general pedagogies and/or specific instructional practices have a well-established empirical basis demonstrating their effectiveness (or lack thereof)? (2) What general pedagogies and/or specific instructional practices are in need of further research to establish an empirical basis demonstrating their effectiveness (or lack thereof)?

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
For more than half a century the Mathematical Association of America (www.maa.org) has provided national leadership on the development and dissemination of guidelines for undergraduate programs in mathematics. Now, moving beyond curriculum issues and with support from NSF, the MAA has developed an important, complementary resource: a guide to evidenced-based instructional practices in undergraduate mathematics, written by teams of mathematicians and mathematics education researchers, to provide support for undergraduate mathematics instructors.

Maintaining vibrant undergraduate mathematics programs that both attract and retain students from a variety of backgrounds is crucial not only for mathematics, but for our society as a whole. In spite of tremendous growth in undergraduate enrollments during the latter decades of the 20th century and the increasing need for mathematical sophistication in many careers, the number of majors in the mathematical sciences and other STEM disciplines has not kept pace, but rather has remained relatively constant. Further, the participation of minorities remains low, and while about half of all undergraduate mathematics majors are women, many fewer women than men go on to postgraduate study in mathematics.

It is now well-established by cognitive science and education research that effectively implemented student-centered instructional practices have a positive impact on student success in undergraduate science and mathematics courses. Yet relatively few students currently experience such student-centered instructional practices. A major obstacle to student success in entry-level STEM courses is a lack of faculty adoption and use of evidence-based, student-centered teaching methods. The research literature has made the case and various professional associations have amplified the conclusion: active, student-centered instruction is more effective for student learning as well as for addressing equity and inclusion.

The primary goal and central achievement of this project has been the creation of the MAA Instructional Practices Guide (MAA IP Guide), grounded in mathematics education literature, including research in undergraduate mathematics education, K-12 education research, teacher training research, and K-20 policy documents. A key strength of the MAA IP Guide is that it was developed by mathematicians working together with researchers in undergraduate mathematics education in order to ensure an accurate, effective translation of education research into practice. As a result of this project, this guide now serves as a research-based resource for faculty and graduate students for improving teaching and learning in mathematical sciences departments at all types of higher education institutions. As part of the long-running MAA Notes series, the guide has significant visibility within the community. As of this reporting, the download page has had roughly 20,000 unique visitors, the guide has been a centerpiece for professional development at local, regional, and national venues, and explicit connections to other projects and communities are on the rise.

The project to create the guide spanned a four-year period of time and involved more than 150 members of the mathematical sciences and STEM professional communities, comprising 6 leadership team members, 16 advisory board members, 8 steering committee members, 38 additional writers, 65 participants in focus groups, and numerous other community members who provided input on the guide over the duration of the project. The project also included a supplement that served to pilot some research methodology on the uptake of professional development experiences by new instructors, research that will inform the MAA and the broader mathematics community on effective practices for professional development in teaching. Finally, the funding project ends with the establishment of an online community called the Active Learning Exchange on the MAA Connect platform, which will bring together resources, research, and kindred spirits from other projects focused on active learning and evidence-based instructional practices. Since this online community will be managed and nourished by the MAA Committee on the Teaching of Undergraduate Mathematics, the ongoing benefits of the MAA IP Guide are fully institutionalized, and we expect to realize the vision of the guide as a living document to serve the community for years to come.
